INTRODUCTION

2.
The Government of Pakistan recognizes the serious implications of poor women’s health
and  high  population  growth,  and  desires  to  improve  the  reproductive  health  (RH)  status  of
women  and  accelerate  the  pace  of  fertility  decline.  It  plans  to  do  so  by  strengthening  the
Population  Welfare  Program  (PWP)  of  the  Ministry  of  Population  Welfare  (MOPW)  and
provincial  population  welfare  departments  (PPWDs),  and  the  National  Program  of  Family
Planning and Primary Health Care (NPFP) of the Ministry of Health (MOH) and provincial health
departments (PHDs). The Government aims to introduce the RH approach in line with the 1994
Cairo Resolution, promoting an integrated package of RH interventions aligned to the priorities
of the people. In Pakistan, these priorities are family planning (FP), maternal care, infant care,
and control of reproductive tract infections (RTI) and sexually transmitted diseases (STDs). The
Government is planning to integrate maternal and child health (MCH) and FP services into the
RH  approach  to  make  them  more  acceptable,  efficient,  and  effective;  and  extend  basic  RH
services to all Pakistani. Many poor rural communities do not have access to basic RH services
at  present.  As  part  of  its  overall  restructuring  of  the  public  sector,  the  Government  plans  to
merge the population welfare and health structures, decentralize RH programs to the provinces,
and devolve administrative powers to the district level.

3.
The support of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to the health and population welfare
sectors  has  contributed  substantially  to  meeting  the  Government’s  targets  for  the  eighth  five-
year plan, 1993-1998.1 Under the umbrella of the Social Action Program (SAP), the Government
has  requested  ADB  to  help  introduce  the  RH  approach,  and  expand  RH  services  in  poor
districts  not  included  in  ADB’s  Women’s  Health  Project  or  other  projects.2  Project  preparatory
technical  assistance3  for  the  Reproductive  Health  Project  was  done  from  July  to  December
2000.  A  participatory  approach  was  used  with  extensive  consultations  of  government  officers,
field  staff,  beneficiaries,  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs),  and  the  private  sector.  The
Appraisal  Mission4  visited  Punjab,  Sindh,  and  North-West  Frontier  Province  (NWFP)  and  met
with the Government, aid agencies, and NGO representatives to discuss the proposed Project,
including possible cofinancing. The project framework is in Appendix 1.

Sector Description

Economic and Social Context

4.
Pakistan is the seventh most populous country in the world with an estimated 143 million
people in 2001. At the current population growth of 2.3 percent, it will have 243 million people in
2025.5  The  rapid  population  growth  has  negated  the  impact  of  development  and  exacerbated
poverty.  Pakistan  has  poor  human  development  indicators,  marked  by  inequities  between
women and men, income groups, and urban and rural populations. The social sector has been
neglected  for  many  years;  public  sector  expenditure  for  the  social  sector  is  still  very  small—
around  2 percent of gross  domestic product for education, and less than 1 percent for health.
SAP, initiated in 1992, resulted in only modest improvement of the country's social indicators, as
it  had  to  overcome  major  political,  economic,  and  institutional  constraints.  Continuous  social
sector  reform  and  substantially  increased  investments  are  required  to  build  human  and
institutional capacity, change attitudes and practices, and improve family health.

5.
The social structure, customs, and beliefs in Pakistan’s more traditional society result in
women  and  girls  having  less  access  to  nutrition,  education,  health  care,  and  employment.
Levels of literacy and educational attainment remain very low, especially for rural women. The
1998 census shows that in rural areas only 21 percent of women and 47 percent of men were
literate, compared with 55.6 percent of urban women and 72.6 percent of urban men. Women's
participation  in  formal  employment  was  only  13.6  percent.  The  social  conditions  of  women
inhibit them from making decisions and choices about their health, nutrition, and child bearing,
particularly in rural Pakistan, which has the highest fertility and maternal mortality ratios.

The national per capita income was about $446 equivalent in 2000. Poverty increased,
6.
and income distribution worsened in the 1990s. Poverty increased to about 30-35 percent of the
population.6  Based  on  the  head  count  approach,  the  proportion  of  poor  rural  and  urban
households increased, respectively, from 18 to 35 percent, and 15 to 26 percent in the period
FY 1987/88-FY1998/99. 7 Poverty is deeper and more rampant in rural areas, where it is closely
linked to land ownership, large family size, unemployment, and lack of social services. Poverty
is more prevalent in rural Sindh and Balochistan. Forty-four percent of the population works in
agriculture, which was hit by persistent drought in the past few years.

7.
In  addition  to  rising  poverty,  Pakistan  faces  severe  macroeconomic  imbalances,
declining  economic  growth,  and  underdeveloped  human  capital.  Pakistan's  overall  fiscal
situation is precarious following several national and international events. In FY2001, the budget
deficit  was  reduced  to  5.2  percent,  which  is  the  lowest  deficit  in  20  years.    However,  chronic
fiscal  and  external  deficits  have  resulted  in  the  accumulation  of  large  domestic  and  external
debt,  equal  to  115  percent  of  gross  domestic  product  in  2001.  The  country  has  successfully
negotiated  a  poverty  reduction  growth  facility  program  with  the  International  Monetary  Fund,
which is expected to be approved in December 2001.

2.

Reproductive Health

8.
While the population is still growing due to the large number of young couples entering
reproductive  age,  the  fertility  of  couples  has  actually  been  declining  in  rural  and  urban  areas.
Pakistan’s total fertility rate declined from 7.1 in 1965-1969 to 4.8 in 2000, compared with 3.7 in
Bangladesh and 2.3 in Sri Lanka. Important causes of the decline include higher average age at
marriage  and  higher  use  of  contraceptives  among  women  beyond  30  years  of  age.  The
contraceptive  prevalence  rate  has  increased  remarkably  from  12  to  28  percent  in  the  last
decade. The rise in the contraceptive prevalence rate is conspicuous in rural areas, where it is
linked  to  the  increasing  number  of  community-based  workers  and  economic  pressures  on  the
household.  Knowledge  of  contraceptive  methods  has  now  reached  almost  every  married
couple. As a result of the increasing desire to limit family size, the unmet need for contraception
increased from 28 to 38 percent between 1990/91 and 1996/97, indicating a major shortfall in
services. 8

Each  year,  about  5  million  children  are  born  in  Pakistan.  While  the  use  of  antenatal

motherhood has not become much safer. Most rural women deliver at home, where malnutrition
and  illness,  obstetric  complications,  and  harmful  birth  practices  of  traditional  birth  attendants
(TBAs)  and  relatives  often  result  in  maternal  disabilities  and  deaths  that  could  have  been
prevented  if  basic  quality  obstetric  care  was  available.  About  18  percent  of  women  use
institutions for childbirth. These women do not always receive quality care, which discourages
institutional delivery. About 20,000 Pakistani women die from maternal complications each year,
and  one  third  of  women  suffer  an  obstetric  disability.  In  1997,  the  maternal  mortality  ratio
estimate  ranged  from  340  to  600  per  100,000  live  births.9  Rural  women  are  at  much  greater

begins  at  an  early  age,  when  the  risk  of  maternal  complications  is  very  high.  Abortions  and

10.
About  450.000  million  infants  of  the  5  million  born  each  year  die  before  reaching  their
first birthday. The infant mortality rate has fallen from 137 per 1,000 live births in 1960 to 89 per
1,000  live  births  in  1998,10  but  this  is  still  high  compared  with  15  per  1,000  live  births  in  Sri
Lanka.11  One  quarter  of  all  children  are  born  with  low  birth  weight,  mainly  due  to  maternal
malnutrition.  About  half  of  infant  mortality  occurs  within  one  month  after  birth,  and  is  closely
related  to  maternal  care.  Respiratory  infections  and  diarrheal  diseases  cause  most  infant
deaths. Childhood diseases like tetanus and measles are declining as immunization coverage of
women and infants has reached respectively 31 and 45 percent.

The Reproductive Health Sector

12.
Since  the  1950s,  the  RH  sector  has  progressed  through  several  distinct  phases.  It
started with the provision of services through female paramedics, followed by the introduction of
the FP program, the expansion of rural health services, and mass media education. Community-
based services first developed in the 1980s through lady health visitors (LHVs) on an outreach
basis, followed by training of TBAs and family health workers (FHWs) form the local community.
The  current  approach  aims  to  increase  access  to  RH  care  through  FHWs;  making  quality
emergency  obstetric  care  (EmOC)  available;  education  of  males;  NGO  support;  and  social
marketing. A summary of the RH sector is in Appendix 3.

13.
The impact of population programs in the first four decades was less than expected. In
addition  to  an  initial  public  resistance  against  modern  FP  methods,  there  were  some
programmatic issues: (i) weak political commitment, (ii) frequent policy and structural changes,
(iii) lack of an integrated  service delivery approach, (iv) exclusive focus on married women as
the  target  group,  (v)  limited  coverage  of  services,  (vi)  interference  of  local  leaders,  (vii)  weak
governance, and (viii) inadequate investments.

14.
A  noticeable  change  in  FP  appeared  in  the  1990s,  with  stronger  political  commitment,
more funds, better governance, and the introduction of FHWs. But efforts in making motherhood
safer  met  with  far  less  success.  First,  safe  motherhood  requires  effective  services  at  various
levels  in  the  health  system  and  cannot  be  addressed  on  a  campaign  basis.  Second,  because
maternal  mortality  affects  mainly  poor  rural  women  at  home,  it  has  not  received  priority  from
leaders and health services managers. Growing awareness of the suffering of these women(cid:190)
for  every  maternal  death,  30  more  women  become  disabled(cid:190) and  the  socioeconomic
consequences of their disability or death in poor households led to an increasing Government
commitment to reach poor women to make motherhood safer. At the same time, there is greater
public openness and concern about the increase in RTIs, STDs, and adolescent health.

MOPW  is  responsible  for  population  policies  and  the  PWP.  The  PWP  is  implemented
15.
through the PPWDs in each of the four provinces, and in federal areas and institutions directly
under  MOPW. PPWDs  have  not  been established as full provincial departments, but this may
change  as  federal  staff  is  currently  being  transferred  to  the  provincial  administration.  The
delivery system includes 1,688 family welfare centers, 266 RH services centers, and 131 mobile
service  units.  It  also  included  12,072  female  village-based  family  planning  workers  (VBFPWs)
that  have  been  transferred  to  the  NPFP.  The  1,052  male  VBFPWs,  responsible  for  male
education on FP, remain with the PWP. Each family welfare center, managed or headed by a
paramedic  family  welfare  worker,  offers  FP  counseling,  nonsurgical  contraceptives,  and  MCH
care  for  about  6,000  people.  A  token  amount  is  charged  for  contraceptives.  The  RH  services
centers  provide  surgical  and  clinical  contraception.  Twelve  regional  training  institutes  provide
clinical training; and three population welfare training institutes, nonclinical training.

16.
MOH  is  responsible  for  health  policies  and  operates  eight  federal  programs,  including
the  NPFP  and  five  tertiary  hospitals.  PHDs  operate  in  the  four  provincial  governments.  Their
combined  delivery  system  includes  918  district  and  subdistrict  hospitals,  559  rural  health
centers,  4,718  basic  health  units,  935  MCH  centers,  and  dispensaries.  In  each  province,
promotive,  preventive,  and  curative  health  services  are  delivered  through  a  four-tier  system:
FHWs at community level, primary care facilities at union council level, first referral hospitals at

 5

Government  has  combined  the  43,000  lady  health  workers  and  12,072  female  VBFPW  into
FHWs  under  the  NPFP.  The  FHW  carries  out  registration,  counseling,  minor  treatment,  FP
services,  and  referral.  She  visits  households  each  month  in  a  catchment  population  of  up  to

17.
On 14 August 2001, the Government established the district government and devolved
powers to the district government through the promulgation of the Local Government Ordinance
by all the provinces. The district government will appoint a district executive officer (health) who
will  be  responsible  for  managing  the  district  health  and  population  team  (DHPT)  including  all
health and population welfare services in the district. This is likely to become fully effective by 1
July 2002 under the proposed name of District Health Group.

18.
The private sector accounts for nearly two thirds of all health expenditure and is largely
urban-based,  providing  curative  services.  A  small  percentage  of  private  practitioners  offer
comprehensive  RH  service  to  both  females  and  males,  and  less  than  2  percent  received  FP
training  in  the  past  three  years.  The  NGO  sector,  almost  nonexistent  at  the  time  of
independence,  has  steadily  grown  over  the  years,  particularly  the  last  two  decades.  It  is
estimated that there are now more than 16,000 NGOs: the majority of them are working at the
community level, about 25 percent at the subdistrict or district level, and about 5 percent at the
national level. Some of them supplement public sector efforts with RH advocacy, education, and
services.  In  1994,  the  Government  established  an  autonomous  umbrella  organization,  the
National  Trust  for  Population  Welfare.  It  has  supported  about  200  NGO  proposals  for  FP
services. Two social marketing projects, "Key" and "Green Star", have made some progress in
providing contraceptives but their market shares remain small.

Health Sector Financing

In 1992, the Government initiated the SAP to address the serious neglect of the social
19.

The first phase of the SAP (1992-1996) achieved its expenditure and performance targets in the
health  and  population  welfare  sector.  At  present,  the  Government  is  implementing  the  second

B.

Government Policies and Plans

23.
Since the 1950s, the Government has been implementing various policies to address the
poor  health  status  of  women  and  children  and  high  population  growth  through  MCH/FP
programs  (Appendix  4).14  The  policies  show  distinct  phases:  (i)  providing  static  MCH  services
through female paramedics, (ii) introducing selective FP programs, (iii) posting doctors in rural
areas, (iv) adding outreach services, (v) expanding health infrastructure, (vi) training TBAs, (vii)
improving obstetric services, (viii) introducing community-based workers, (ix) increasing support
for  NGOs,  and  (x) introducing  social  marketing.15  While  the  Family  Planning  Association  of
Pakistan started services as early as 1953, the role of NGOs has remained small.

These frequent policy changes reflect initial problems with achieving impact. It took time
24.
to  develop  support  for  women’s  health  and  fertility  regulation  in  a  nonconducive  environment.
There  was  inadequate  political  commitment  and  support  among  leaders.  Frequent  changes  in
policies and structures reduced implementation efforts. Plans did not consider how difficult it is
for  women  to  travel  and  work  in  isolated  places,  while  doctors  lacked  interest  in  FP  services.
After substantial investments in training TBAs, it was realized that it was difficult to change their
behavior even with proper training and support. The lack of an integrated approach resulted in
FP services not being available in the large network of health facilities. Leadership in the sector
kept  changing  and  weak  management  affected  staff  productivity.  Inadequate  funding  and
logistics resulted in shortages of drugs and contraceptives.

25.
In  the  1990s,  the  overall  climate  for  women’s  health  and  FP  became  more  conducive.
The  Government  formulated  policies  to  respond  to  the  1994  International  Conference  on
Population and Development, for incorporation in the 9th five-year plan (1998-2003). MOPW and
MOH  jointly  formulated  a  national  vision  and  package  for  RH  services  in  Pakistan.16  MOPW
adopted a comprehensive population and development policy, aimed at broadening the scope
of services for a transition from FP services to the RH approach, without losing focus on fertility
control.  The  present  Government  expresses  great  concern  about  the  implications  of  high
population  growth  for  poverty  and  economic  development.  It  seeks  to  reduce  fertility  and
maternal and infant mortality rates, and promote gender equity and women empowerment. On
World Population Day, 11 July 2000, the chief executive admonished the nation to address the
population  explosion  on  a  war  footing;  and  devise  strategies  to  bring  down  the  population

Lessons Learned

According to the sector synthesis,20 the designs of ADB-financed health and population
34.
projects21 were generally in line with the Government's priorities and programs, and appropriate
in  scope  and  strategies.  The  projects  had  a  strong  focus  on  improving  access  to  basic  health
services for the poor, women, and children; and training of female health staff and managers.
The evaluation noted further that merely providing health facilities was not sufficient to improve
coverage,  and  more  attention  should  have  been  given  to  district  management  and  training.
More recent projects present an integrated health systems development approach based on in-
depth analysis of institutional constraints and efforts to address the shortfall through policy and
institutional reforms, capacity building, and partnerships.

Implementation  problems  caused  on  average  two  years  of  project  delay.  The  project
35.
performance  audit  report  of  the  Second  Health  and  Population  Project22  noted  several
problems:  (i)  lack  of  preparedness  of  the  Government  agencies  concerned,  (ii)  lack  of
management  skills  and  understanding  of  ADB  procedures,  (iii)  frequent  transfers  of  key
personnel,  (iv)  lack  of  aid  agency  cooperation,  and  (v) slow  implementation  of  civil  works.
Project Directors were appointed late and transferred frequently, and often lacked competency
and  authority.  The  SAPPII  midterm  review  in  2000  observed  that  the  limited  staff  capacity  at
provincial and district levels is slowing down program implementation.

36.
A review of other external assistance identified a number of critical factors that improve
outcomes: strong political commitment, alignment with the Government's core program, building
a  pool  of  public  health  professionals,  access  to  technical  assistance,  streamlining  of
administrative procedures, and incentive packages. The sustainability of project benefits largely
depended on (i) Government commitment, (ii) the level of incremental costs of projects, (iii) the
inclusion  of  these  costs  in  the  regular  budget,  and  (iv)  the  continuing  presence  of  adequately
trained staff. The project design provides several actions to mitigate delays and improve project
quality. The Project will enhance management capacity by training, delegating responsibilities,
strengthening RH Directorates, and providing additional staff inputs.

37.
Regarding  RH,  the  projects  show  that  FHWs  are  effective,  and  that  it  is  possible  to
recruit them from traditional communities. Communication strategies have generally also been
successful.  However,  the  fact  that  the  district  executive  officer  (health)  and  medical  officers  in
charge  of  health  facilities  often  do  not  give  priority  to  MCH/FP  services  has  hampered  the
impact  of  MCH/FP  programs.  Therefore,  a  strong  institutional  commitment  to  RH  is  essential.
RH  projects  should  be  an  integral  part  of  district  health  system  development.  This  will  also
improve  the  sustainability  of  RH  interventions.  The  international  aid  community,  urgently
seeking  results,  has  shifted  to  a  revival  of  vertical  programs  for  the  control  of  infectious
diseases,  resulting  in  a  fragmented  and  unsustainable  campaign  approach  to  resolving  public
health  problems.  It  is  important  that  the  Government  and  funding  agencies  adhere  to  an
integrated PHC approach in Pakistan.

between  family  size  and  self-perpetuating  poverty,  and  promotes  enhancing  the  quality  of
women's lives by giving priority to providing accessible RH services. The Project addresses the
three  core  pillars  of  the  strategy:  it  is  targeting  RH  services  for  the  poor,  which  will  help  them
improve their livelihood. ADB's poverty reduction strategy also emphasizes that denial of basic
services to the poor is not just a matter of lack of investment, but often a result of governance
problems  and  lack  of  participation  by  the  poor.  The  strategy  promotes  sound  public
administration  and  expenditure  management 
to  promote  pro-poor  growth  and  social
development;  and  devolution  of  public  services  to  the  lowest  appropriate  level  of  government.
The Project contributes to improving governance and devolving services.

39.
ADB's  country  assistance  plan  for  Pakistan's  health  sector  focuses  on  (i)  improving
public  sector  governance  and  efficiency  by  strengthening  management  and  public-private
partnership, and (ii) increasing equity by improving access of women to quality health services.
In addition, ADB's focus on girls' education offer important opportunities for synergy.

In line with ADB's health policy, ADB's approach in the health sector is threefold.24 First,
40.
it aims to ensure that the poor and vulnerable have access to PHC. Pakistan's PHC network is
quite  extensive.  However,  women  have  less  access  to  PHC  and  carry  the  burden  of  high

agencies provide complementary support for control of communicable diseases. Second, it aims
to improve governance, efficiency, and sustainability in the health sector through health sector
reform, including support for integration of services, devolution, public-private partnership, and
private  sector  regulation.  Third,  it  aims  to  improve  the  quality  of  project  design  and
implementation  through  a  health  systems  approach,  district  level  participatory  planning,
management capacity building, and monitoring and evaluation including district surveys. These
priorities are reflected in the project design.

IV.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT

A.

Rationale

Pakistan's rapid population growth at the rate of 2.3 percent per annum has exacerbated
47.
poverty and negated the impact of development in the last decade. While fertility is declining, it
has  the  potential  to  accelerate  given  the  high  unmet  demand  for  FP.  Health  status  indicators
have not improved much over the past decade. The maternal mortality ratio is still very high due
to poor birth practices at community, primary, and hospital levels. Much more work is needed at
all  levels  to  make  motherhood  safer.  Better  maternal  care  would  substantially  reduce  infant
mortality, including that caused by infections and malnutrition.

48.
The Government accords high priority to improving the poor health status of women and
children, and reducing high population growth. It seeks to accelerate the pace of fertility decline,
introduce  quality  RH  services,  and  promote  gender  equity  and  women  empowerment.  It  is
strengthening its RH policy, particularly for safe motherhood. The Government plans a transition
from  separate  FP  and  MCH  services  to  the  RH  approach  to  improve  the  acceptability  and
efficiency  of  RH  services.  The  Government  gives  priority  to  expanding  RH  in  poor  and
underserved  districts,  and  involving  NGOs  and  other  stakeholders.  The  Government’s
commitment to RH has been demonstrated by a significant increase in its funding for RH in the
past decade.

49.
The  Project  is  targeting  34  districts  in  the  third  and  fourth  quartiles  in  terms  of  social
ranking, excluding those targeted by other projects. At least 50 percent of project beneficiaries
will  be  poor.  The  proposed  interventions  are  simple,  inexpensive,  and  cost-effective;  they  will
address  the  needs  of  the  poor  and  support  sustainable  development.  ADB  has  successfully
assisted the Government's PWP to achieve the targets for the 8th five-year plan. Recurrent cost
implications after project completion are estimated at only 2 percent of the Government's health
budget. The project design is in line with ADB's poverty reduction strategy, policy for the health
sector, and country strategy.

B.

Objectives and Scope

50.
The overall goal of the Project is to improve the RH status of families, reduce maternal
and  infant  mortality,  and  reduce  population  growth.  The  Project  will  contribute  to  improving
women’s  health  and  social  status  and  reducing  poverty.  The  objectives  are  to:  (i)  improve  the
quality,  access  and  acceptance  of  RH  services  in  34  poor  and  underserved  districts,  and  (ii)
strengthen the sector’s capacity for RH services in the context of the Government’s restructuring
process, including though NGOs and the private sector.

51.
The  Project  will  be  implemented  nation-wide,  with  focus  on  34  selected  districts  in  4
provinces  (10  in  Punjab  and  8  each  in  Balochistan,  North-West  Frontier  Province  and  Sindh).
Six components will address the project objectives:

1.

Improve the Quality of RH Services

52.
The  Project  will  improve  the  quality  of  RH  services  by  introducing  the  RH  package,
providing  in-service  training,  and  integrating  services.  With  the  assistance  of  the  technical
working group, the Project will develop the RH package and delivery system into a skills-based
training program. Consulting services will be provided for developing standard RH practices and

 14

curricula,  and  training  of  trainers.  The  Project  will  provide  in-service  training  for  LHWs,  male
VBFPWs, midwives, LHVs, family welfare workers, and female and male medical officers, and
orientation  of  other  staff  in  the  targeted  districts.  The  in-service  training  will  be  use  modern
teaching  methodologies  with  substantial  hands-on  practice.  The  training  will  focus  on  FP,
maternal  health  including  safe  motherhood,  infant  health,  and  management  of  RTI  including
HIV/AIDS. The Project will also introduce a standardized technical and managerial supervision
system, with logistic support for monitoring and field supervision. The Project will upgrade basic
EmOC  services  in  250  rural  health  centers  and  subdistrict  hospitals.  It  will  also  assist  about
2,500  basic  health  and  population  welfare  facilities  in  the  targeted  districts  with  minor  repairs
and supplementary equipment and supplies.

2.

Improve Access to RH Care for the Poor

53.
The Project will improve access at community and hospital levels. The Project will train,
supply,  and  supervise  4,400  female  and  1,200  male  FHWs  in  the  targeted  districts.  Twenty-
eight  mobile  service  units  will  be  added  and  19  will  be  refurbished  for  areas  where  women’s
mobility  is  restricted  and  where  it  is  difficult  to  operate  facilities.  The  Project  will  add  33  RH
centers  and  upgrade  8  RH  centers  to  respond  to  the  increasing  demand  for  surgical
contraception. Only 20 percent of hospitals in the project area provide 24-hour comprehensive
emergency  obstetric  services.  In  each  district,  one  hospital  will  be  upgraded  to  provide
comprehensive  EmOC.  The  referral  system  will  be  promoted  and  made  more  user-friendly
through better marketing.

3.

Promote RH for Specific Target Groups

54.
The  Project  will  promote  awareness  of  RH  needs  and  services,  and  create  a  more
conducive  environment  through  advocacy  among  specific  target  groups  using  interpersonal
communications  (IPC),  group  media,  and  mass  media.  The  Project  will  revive  the  Federal
Communication  Advisory  Group  to  implement  the  IEC  component,  assist  funding  agencies  to
complement each other’s work, adopt common themes and standardize messages, and utilize
resources in the most effective manner. The Health Education and Nutrition Cells in the targeted
districts will be supported with training in new IEC methods, materials and operational support.

55.
The Project will develop IPC skills of FHWs and health staff through on-the-job training,
and provide IEC materials and support services through the district health and nutrition officers.
A  telephone  hotline  will  be  introduced  at  the  district  level.  Religious  scholars  and  male  FHWs
will discuss RH-related issues with local leaders and males. Group media activities will include
“video  on  wheels”  based  on  successful  experiences  in  other  countries.  The  activity  will  be
carried  out  in  collaboration  with  "town  storming",  a  multimedia  marketing  strategy  used  for
advocacy among local leaders, men, women, and adolescents. Commercial spots will be used
during  shows  to  help  offset  the  costs.  FHWs,  in  collaboration  with  local  NGOs,  will  organize
ward  meetings.  Private  sector  firms  will  produce  videos  on  different  topics  for  these  ward
meetings,  which  will  be  dubbed  in  six  local  languages.  Audio/video  materials  developed  by
NGOs  will  also  be  acquired  and  used.  As  television  and  radio  also  reach  the  low-income
population,  these  mass  media  will  be  used  to  convey  information  regarding  FP,  EmOC,  and
other RH issues. The Project will support three formats: short spots, songs, and drama serials.
Radio producers from the 18 radio stations in Pakistan will be trained in producing RH spots and
programs for radio broadcast.

4.

Strengthen RH Management Capacity

56.
The  Project  will  assist  the  Government  to  strengthen  the  planning,  management,  and
monitoring  of  RH  services,  within  the  context  of  integration  of  services,  decentralization  to  the
provinces,  and  devolution  to  the  districts.  The  federal  and  provincial  joint  coordination
committees  will  provide  guidance  and  each  steering  committee  will  oversee  implementation.
The Project will strengthen the federal and provincial directorates of RH and project coordinating
units (PCUs) with consulting services, staff, training, and logistics to support implementation in
districts and training institutions, and plan a comprehensive RH program in each province. It will
also strengthen the health education directorates through fellowships.

57.
The  Project  will  support  the  DHPT  in  each  targeted  district  through  additional  staff,
training, and technical support. Guidelines and training material developed under the Women's
Health Project will be used to conduct district surveys, prepare five year and annual plans, and
provide  training  for  the  district  and  subdistrict  management  teams  in  planning,  procurement,
logistics,  monitoring,  and  personnel  and  financial  management.  A  project  cell  in  the  district
health office, with a full-time planning/procurement officer and an accounts assistant, will serve
as the project implementation unit at district level.

5.

Develop Human Resources for RH

58.
The component will strengthen the preservice training capacity for health staff concerned
with  RH  services.  The  Project  will  upgrade  12  midwifery  schools  in  the  targeted  districts,  and
support  2,000  students  from  underserved  areas  to  attend  midwifery  school.    The  Project  will
improve  23  public  health  schools  to  improve  the  training  of  LHVs.  Trainers  will  be  trained  in
modern teaching methodologies, evaluation techniques, curriculum development, IPC skills, and
hands-on supervised clinical training. In addition, new sites for practical training will be identified
such as subdistrict hospitals, to improve skills training. Adequate facilities, equipment, transport,
furniture, and supplies will be made available as needed. The Project will upgrade 3 population
welfare  training  institutes  for  training  of  male  VBFPWs  in  RH  management;  and  add  3  and
upgrade 7 regional training schools for training in clinical RH services. The training of LHWs will
be relocated from PHC centers to subdistrict hospitals to improve skills training.

6.

Harnessing NGO and Private Sector capacity

59.
The  Project  aims  to  use  the  potential  of  NGOs  and  the  private  sector  to  expand  RH
services. The Project will provide training and supportive activities to 2,500 private practitioners,
4,000  female  paramedics,  and  8,000  drug  shopkeepers  to  expand  and  improve  the  quality  of
RH  services.  A  large  number  of  NGOs  are  providing  RH  services  including  advocacy  for
women’s  status  and  rights,  community  mobilization,  human  resource  development,  health

contraceptives. Studies have shown that the poor are paying for emergency services (mostly for

sector facilities near their homes, provided the charges are reasonable.29 Through established
NGOs,  the  Project  will  support  contracting  of  NGOS  to  expand  RH  services  in  the  targeted
districts,  including  social  mobilization  and  education  activities,  training,  contracting  of  staff,

V.

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION

A.

Financial and Economic Analysis

1.

Financial Analysis

91.
The  Project  has  been  designed  to  support  the  Government’s  efforts  to  contain  public
sector  expansion  and  recurrent  costs.  The  Project  supports  basic  integrated  health  and  FP
services, focusing on the most cost-effective interventions. The civil works have been limited to
upgrading  and  rehabilitating  existing  facilities.  Three  types  of  incremental  recurrent  costs  are
necessary,  namely  (i)  contracting  FHWs  to  reach  populations  not  reached  so  far;  (ii)
supplementing the supply of essential drugs and contraceptives, partly paid for by households;
and (iii) improving the quality of services. The result will be better utilization and more efficient
use  of  existing  infrastructure  and  human  resources.  However,  a  sustained  increase  in  budget
allocation for salaries, supplies, training and supervision will also be needed. The total recurrent
expenditure for maintaining activities after project completion is estimated at 2 percent of total
public health expenditure.

92.
Arrangements  are  in  place  to  sustain  the  modest  increase  in  recurrent  costs  resulting
from  the  Project  and  to  increase  sector  spending  for  RH:  (i)  a  policy  framework  giving  high
priority  to  RH,  (ii)  the  follow-up  to  a  SAP  framework  to  improve  financing  of  basic  social
services, and (iii) several policies to improve efficiency in the health sector. The Project will also
support  RH  promotion  and  capacity  building  in  the  RH  directorates  to  increase  sustainability.
SAP  has  given  high  priority  to  nonsalary  allocation,  which  has  increased  in  all  provinces  to
about  one  third  of  the  total  recurrent  allocation.  The  Project  also  supports  the  Government’s
efforts to improve efficiency by devolving federal and provincial responsibilities to the districts.
The merger of female VBFPWs and LHWs will also improve efficiency. An increased focus on
promotive and preventive services should reduce the burden on curative services. Public-private
initiatives such as training of private practitioners and NGO support will help develop nonpublic
services.

2.

Economic Analysis

a.

Public Sector Intervention

93.
Public investment in RH services can be justified in terms of efficiency and equity. Equity
arguments  in  favor  of  subsidized  health  services  are  strong  in  Pakistan,  where  income  and
expenditure surveys suggest that about one third of the population live below the poverty line.

 25

The provision of services by the public sector, in addition to their financing, is justified in
94.
cases where either private provision is inadequate, the public sector is a more efficient provider,
and/or  consumers  exhibit  a  clear  preference  for  public  services.  The  Pakistan  Fertility  and
Family Planning Survey, 1996/97, shows that 72 percent of clients obtained contraceptive pills
from the private sector outlets, while 60 percent sourced the pills from the public sector, 20 from
social  marketing,  and  20  from  the  commercial  sector.  Similarly,  37  percent  of  clients  obtained
injections  from  the  private  sector,  and  4  percent  from  NGOs,  but  91  percent  of  the  injections
were financed by the Government. This suggests that the public sector has an important role in
financing contraceptives, while the private sector is important in delivering them. However, this
balance needs to be understood in terms of market and institutional constraints. For rural areas,
the public sector will continue to have an important delivery function in the near future.

The private sector often does not provide a full range of RH services; and the costs are
95.
substantially higher than in the public sector. However, given the limited public sector capacity,
the  private  sector,  wherever  it  is  capable  of  providing  goods  and  services  in  an  efficient  and
cost-effective manner, should be encouraged, and the possibility of public subsidies considered.
 
96.
It appears that a higher proportion of the poor perceive RH problems as less important,
despite  their  being  more  common  among  the  poor.  In  view  of  the  population’s  low  willingness
and ability to pay, and with the profit-motivated private sector providing the services, it is feared
that  the  real  “target  class”  i.e.,  the  poor  class,  will  be  marginalized  and  the  relatively  affluent
classes,  mostly  residing  in  urban  centers,  will  be  served.  Thus,  to  ensure  wider  coverage  of
services for the rural poor, direct public service delivery is required.

If the public sector invests directly in RH service delivery rather than merely depending
97.
on regulation, it will not only address the issue of poverty reduction, but also improve equity by
reducing rural/urban imbalances. Gender balance, too, will improve as RH interventions address
women's health besides promoting female employment.

b.

Justification for Increased Funding

98.
The  level  of  public  sector  funding  is  concerned  with  the  requirements  to  meet  public
policy objectives and the existing capacity of the public sector delivery system.33 The budget for
PWP  is  relatively  small,  and  the  budget  for  RH  activities  under  the  PHDs  is  not  much  larger.
Given  the  large  unmet  needs  of  RH  in  the  sector,  a  substantial  increase  in  allocations  is
justified. In view of the current tight fiscal situation in the provinces, the federal Government has
agreed to continue financing the federal programs during the next plan period.

99.
The overall rate of utilization for the population and health sector allocations was above
80  percent  during  the  1990s.  Devolving  the  administrative  and  delivery  system  is  expected  to
improve  program  effort.  This  will  include  procurement  of  drugs  and  contraceptives.  Making
allocations available early in the fiscal year will also improve absorptive capacity and efficiency.

c.

User Charges

100.
The  share  of  health  care  expenditures  in  the  total  household  budget,  about  3  percent,
remains  low  across  income  groups.  The  low-income  classes  in  Pakistan  dissave,  i.e.,  on
average, spend more than their incomes. This reflects their very low ability to pay for more, or

more expensive services. The average monthly expenditures on health care increase as income
levels rise, reflecting that people want to pay for more or better health care if they can afford to.

101.
The estimated cost of protection against conception for one year per couple is low.  The
monthly price of oral contraceptive pills, condoms, intrauterine devices, and depot injections are
only PRs3.00 in the public sector, reflecting a policy of subsidy for contraceptives.34 Imposition
or  increase  of  user  charges  on  social  services  is  a  major  issue  in  Pakistan.  It  is  not  known
whether  raising  the  price  of  RH  services  will  affect  the  users'  ability  to  pay,  and  significantly
reduce demand. MOPW suggests that a small fee may increase the use of services as people
expect to receive better services. While RH services are provided at nominal costs, clients often
have to purchase their own medicines and other supplies. As reported by one study, delivering
in a Government facility costs on average PRs590 compared with the average nominal charge
of  PRs24,  as  patients  have  to  purchase  their  own  medicines  from  private  drug  stores.  NGOs
and private clinics were found to be more expensive.35

102.
The rationale is strong for not increasing user charges for the services assisted by the
Project.  The  Project  is  targeting  poor  and  underserved  rural  women.  While  families  may  be
willing  to  pay  for  medical  expenses,  these  may  not  be  within  the  household  budget,  or  may
affect other essential expenditures like for food. Because of the low social status of women, they
may  be  denied  services  if  user  charges  are  increased.  Costs  attached  to  using  public  health
services such as transportation, medicine, and informal charges are already substantial. Given
the low level of public confidence in services at present, a substantial increase in user charges
is  likely  to  result  in  reduced  utilization  of  services  and  efficiency.  Experience  has  shown  that
cost  recovery  in  these  conditions  can  barely  cover  the  administrative  costs.  Therefore,  while
increasing  user  charges  may  have  potential  benefits  in  terms  of  improving  ownership,
accountability, and transparency, it may have adverse effects on the poor, and will not help in
financing  health  services.  In  this  context,  the  social  benefits  of  providing  the  service  to  low-
income groups most certainly outweigh the efficiency gains from cost recovery.

d.

Cost Effectiveness

103.
In health projects, an alternative approach in estimating project benefits is the disability
adjusted  life  years  approach.  This  approach  involves  the  construction  of  a  composite  index  of
the  years  of  health  life  lost  due  to  disease,  disability,  or  death,  and  the  benefits  that  can  be
achieved by saving those lost years. Based on the available data for RH diseases, the cost per
disability adjusted life years saved was calculated as $21. This is considered cost-effective by
international standards (Appendix 12).

B.

Social Dimensions and Poverty Impact

1.

Poverty and Health

104.

even basic health care may not be affordable. Any serious illness including chronic diseases like
tuberculosis  or  conditions  requiring  hospitalization,  and  any  loss  of  labor  that  reduces  the
family’s production capacity will result in food shortage and impoverishment. Access to quality
health services provided under the Project will not only reduce direct and indirect costs of health

2.

Targeting the Poor

105.
The  Project  aims  to  help  overcome  the  gap  in  RH  services  for  the  poor  by  improving
access to quality RH services in the least developed districts. Using a participatory approach, 34
rural  districts  were  selected  on  the  basis  of  social  ranking  (districts  in  the  bottom  and  third
quartiles in terms of socioeconomic development), low ratio of female FHWs, and availability of
external assistance.36 In addition, the Project will target the poor: (i) focusing on providing basic
services  where  the  poor  are  more  likely  to  capture  the  benefits  of  Government  subsidies,  (ii)
selectively  investing  in  services  that  directly  support  RH;  (iii) addressing  RH  conditions  that
disproportionately  affect  the  poor;  and  (iv) identifying,  setting  targets,  and  monitoring  the
Project’s  impact  on  the  very  poor  through  local  committees  and  surveys.  It  is  expected  that
more than 50 percent of the project beneficiaries will be poor (see Appendix 11).

3.

Demand for RH Services 

106. Despite an increasing awareness about health and health services, a significant number
of these women either do not get health care or seek traditional means of health care. About 50
percent of the women, most of them living in small villages, do not have access to basic health
services such as a LHW providing education, FP, and basic medical care. Many couples want to
use modern contraceptives, but find services unavailable within their vicinity. While poverty can
increase  the  vulnerability  to  RH  risks,  ignorance  and  misconceptions  about  RH-related  issues
often  aggravate  existing  problems.  Delay  in  using  health  services  is  often  caused  by  lack  of
awareness about women’s health needs and risks. These attitudes of the husband and family
towards pregnancy, emergencies and hospitals often cause delays. Restrictions on the mobility
of women due to purdah (seclusion) are based on sociocultural and religious traditions. In more
rural  areas,  lack  of  motorized  transport  is  a  major  problem.  Concerns  about  the  costs  and
opportunity costs of health services are also an important factor.

C.

Benefits

107.
The  Project  will  target  the  poor  and  underserved  populations  in  both  rural  and  urban
areas nationwide. The targeted districts are most of Pakistan’s poorest districts from the bottom
and third quartiles with the poorest socioeconomic indicators and a majority of poor people.  The
Project  will  cover  42  million  people,  including  7.7  million  women  of  reproductive  age  and  one
million infants.

108.
The target groups, particularly women and infants, will benefit from increased awareness
about  RH  issues  and  better  medical  care  at  home  (through  well-trained  LHWs),  at  the  health
facilities,  and  at  the  hospitals  (through  24-hour  EmOC).  Contraceptive  prevalence  will  rise,
fertility levels will fall, and both maternal and infant morbidity and mortality rates will decline. The
prevalence  of  anemia  and  incidence  of  STDs  will  decrease.  The  Project  will  directly  benefit
about one third of the population in the targeted districts; reduce the burden of disease for poor
women  and  infants  by  10-30  percent  depending  on  the  type  of  intervention;  prevent  11,000

FHWs  and  paramedics.  It  will  upgrade  training  capacity  in  district  and  subdistrict  hospitals,

D.

Risks

114. Pakistan’s social sector spending has been adversely affected by slow economic growth,
low revenue collection, and declining external assistance. The persistent drought in Balochistan
and  Sindh  has  seriously  affected  the  living  conditions  of  the  poor.  A  sharp  drop  in  foreign
investment followed the terrorist attack on 11 September 2001. The Government and provinces
are  facing  an  acute  fiscal  crisis  for  a  combination  of  reasons,  including  the  decline  in
investments  and  exports,  drought,  refugees,  and  a  shortfall  in  revenues.  Encouraged  by  aid
agencies, the Government, however, is determined to give high priority to the social sector.

115. While the Government is not planning to expand the network of facilities, it is currently
not spending enough to adequately operate the network and finance better services. Improving
the  quality  of  care  will  result  in  higher  recurrent  costs  as  it  will  increase  utilization  rates,  and
increase  unit  cost  per  patient  for  quality  inputs.  The  Government's  exposure  to  health  sector
spending is very modest at about 0.8 percent of gross domestic product. The Government will
have  to  increase  this  percentage  in  the  years  ahead,  or  reduce  the  network  of  services  and
staff.  An  analysis  of  the  counterpart  fund  requirements  suggests  that  the  recurrent  cost
implications  of  the  Project  are  as  low  as  2  percent  of  sector  spending,  mainly  for  new  FHWs.

 29

The Government is also working on improving efficiency, e.g., through devolution and hospital
autonomy. ADB is providing advisory technical assistance to develop a master plan for health
sector  reform  in  NWFP.37  As  the  provincial  governments  are  facing  a  tight  fiscal  situation,  the
provincial contributions have been kept low, and the federal government will continue financing
the federal PWP and NPFP.

116. Pakistan  is  in  a  major  social  and  governance  transition.  Devolution  of  powers  to  the
district,  which  requires  new  administrative  procedures,  took  place  in  August  2001.  Under  the
devolved  structure,  the  district  government  initially  may  not  give  high  priority  to  RH.  Religious
groups may object to promoting RH interventions like FP and education of adolescents, unless
the  interventions  fully  recognize  and  respect  local  sociocultural  and  religious  values.  The
Government  has  made  a  commitment  to  protect  social  sector  spending,  and  provide  districts
with targeted funds for RH. The design of the Project provides powerful incentives to bring RH
into the mainstream of district health activities, such as media campaigns, support for the district
planning  process,  and  a  substantial  district  budget  for  RH  activities.  The  Project  will  help
increase  district  management  capacity,  provide  service  standards,  and  monitor  district
performance.

117. Sector changes may also affect project implementation. The Government has postponed
the  merger  of  MOPW  and  MOH  into  one  Ministry  of  Health  and  Population  Welfare  and  has
placed this proposal under a review committee. Progress is being made at the provincial level,
as  MOPW  has  started  transferring  its field staff to the provincial administration. The Project is
placed  within  the  RH  directorates,  to  ensure  mainstreaming  and  sustainability  of  the  project
activities.  The  impact  of  training  is  often  diluted  due  to  frequent  transfer  of  staff,  but  this  is
countered by training all staff in the targeted districts, as the staff are usually rotated within the
district. Staff performance has been affected due to limited career opportunities and incentives,
and  because  working  in  rural  areas  is  socially  and  financially  less  attractive  to  staff.
Improvement in governance and devolution are expected to improve staff performance.

118. Contracting  of  NGOs  by  the  Government  has  been  slow.  The  Project  provides  for  a
coordinating  NGO to  help  administer the contracting of NGOs. Most NGOs working in the RH
sector  require  capacity  building  in  planning,  management,  and  accounting  if  working  with  the
Government  and  ADB.  Capacity  building  is  being  provided  through  SAPPII  and  projects  of
several aid agencies and international NGOs. However, the coordinating NGO will also provide
project orientation, training, and technical support to the districts and NGOs.

1.
Demography. Pakistan's population has increased fourfold since independence in 1947.
Males  have  outnumbered  females  in  all  censuses,  however,  a  slow  but  constant  change  has
been noted, from 117 males per 100 females in 1951 to 108 males per 100 females in 1998. A
steady fall in mortality since the 1950s has led to substantial improvement in life expectancy at
birth, especially for females, with an increase from 48.7 to 64.6 years between 1962-1965 and
1996, compared to males from 52.4 to 63.9 over the same period. The average age at first time
marriage increased from 17 years in 1951 to 22 years in 1997 for females, and from 22 years in
1951 to 26.5 years in 1997 for males.1

Fertility. The  change in Pakistan’s fertility  has remained slow in earlier decades as the
2.
total  fertility  rate  remained  above  six  births  per  woman  for  almost  three  decades.  However,  a
declining trend has become evident, especially over the last decade. The estimates indicate that
the  total  fertility  rate  at  present  is  4.8  compared  with  7.1  in  1965-1969  (in  Bangladesh,  total
fertility rate is currently 3.7). The observed decline in fertility rate is closely related to changes in
the desired and ideal family size. Available data shows a systemic decline in the perceived ideal
family size from 4.9 children in 1984-1985 to 3.6 in 1994-1995. A preference for a son partially
accounts for the current average of 4.2 children per married woman.

3.
Infant Mortality. Infant mortality rate fell from 137 to 89 deaths per 1,000 live births in
the  first  year  of  life  in  1960-1999.  Currently,  about  400,000  infants  die  each  year  in  Pakistan.
About 59 percent of deaths occur in the first month.2 Largely preventable causes of infant death
in  the  first  month  are  prematurity,  growth  retardation,  low  birth  weight,  asphyxia,  birth  injuries,
and infections of the newborn including neonatal tetanus. About 25 percent  of infants are born
with low birth weight, due mainly to maternal malnutrition. In the remaining 11 months, poor care
of acute respiratory infections and diarrheal diseases remain the major causes of death.

4.
Maternal Mortality. The maternal mortality ratio was 340 per 100,000 live births in 1994,
and  varied  from  286  per  100,000  live  births  in  the  squatter  settlements  of  Karachi  to  630  per
100,000  live  births  in  Balochistan,  a  province  with  a  high  proportion  of  small  and  isolated
villages at great distance from health services.3 The maternal mortality ratio is not expected to
have  changed  much  since  then.  Women  at  increased  risk  of  maternal  mortality  and  morbidity
are  young  and  first-time  mothers,  mothers  with  five  or  more  deliveries,  and  those  with  poor
pregnancy  history.  Other  medical  risk  factors  are  malnutrition  and  smoking.  Social  risk  factors
are illiteracy, poverty, induced abortion, and violence against women associated with about 14
percent  of  maternal  deaths.  However,  all  pregnant  women  are  at  risk  from  complications  in
pregnancy,  childbirth,  and  postnatal  period  such  as  bleeding,  hypertension,  obstructed  labor,
and sepsis.

Ethnic Minorities

3.
Pakistani distinguish themselves not only by their social class, gender, and occupation,
but also by their distinct ethnolinguistic groups and related social customs. Despite this regional

of  95  percent  of  the  population.  Among  minorities,  the  Christians  and  Hindus  are  the  more
prominent,  living  mainly  in,  respectively,  eastern  Punjab  and  eastern  Sindh.  Christians  are
commonly found in low-pay jobs such as housekeeping, and many Hindus are employed in the
carpet and textile industries. They are mobile and accept the use of health services, but being
poor, often may not be able to afford such services. Strong social support systems and charity
services that are typical among the wealthier minority groups such as Ismaeli and Parsi are less
evident.  The  project  will  aim  to  include  poor  minorities  by  selecting  family  health  workers
(FHWs) from among them, and incorporate their particular needs, like translation and adaptation
of education materials, in district health plans.

1.

Perceived Needs

In  traditional  rural  villages,  the  woman’s  role  is  perceived  to  be  responsibility  for
4.
domestic chores, labor near home, and preserving the honor and reputation of the family by not
exposing herself to the outside world. From a young age onward, girls in traditional households
are taught to provide, much less to receive. When they get married, they have internalized this
role  and  pass  it  on  to  their  daughters.  Women's  mobility  is  often  restricted,  and  women  have
less access to adequate nutrition and health services. Many of the health and nutrition problems
of  women  are  perceived  as  a  normal  part  of  life.  There  is  also  stigma  associated  with  certain
diseases.  Women  who  believe  that  they  may  be  suffering  from  a  reproductive  or  urinary  tract
infection  are  often  hesitant  to  discuss  the  problem  with  others  and  to  seek  appropriate
treatment.3  Because  of  these  constraints,  women  often  turn  to  traditional  healers  (hakims)  or
spiritual leaders (pirs) within their village for cure for their RH problems.

A.

The Rationale for Public Sector Intervention

Public investment in reproductive health (RH) services is justified on grounds of efficiency
1.
and  equity.  Some  services  are  public  goods  like  mass  media  education,  or  have  positive
externalities. Improvements in maternal health and nutrition increase the survival probabilities and
well-being  of  young  children.  Increased  chances  of  child  survival  will  lead  to  lower  fertility  and
economic  and  environmental  gains.  In  the  absence  of  public  financing,  the  effective  demand  for
and providing them RH services are likely to remain below a socially desirable level. The provision
of  services  by  the  public  sector,  in  addition  to  financing,  is  also  justified  in  cases  where  private
provision is inadequate, the public sector is a more efficient provider, and/or consumers exhibit a
clear preference for public services.

2.
Equity arguments in favor of subsidized health services are also strong in Pakistan; income
and expenditure surveys suggest that one third of the population live below the poverty line.  The
poor  in  Pakistan  have  lesser  access  to  RH  services,  for  its  monetary  and  non-monetary  price  is
unaffordable to many. Heads of poor household often view family planning (FP) and RH issues as
problems  of  lesser  importance.  As  such,  public  sector  intervention  in  the  form  of  regulating  RH
services through price or quality control to protect consumers, rather than direct service delivery,
will not be effective. In the face of the target population’s low ability to pay and low ranking of FP
and RH issues, it is very likely that, when the profit-motivated private sector provides the services,
the poor will be marginalized and the relatively affluent classes, residing mostly in urban centers,
will  be  served.    Direct  public  investment  can  improve  equity  by  reducing  rural/urban  imbalances.
Gender  balance,  too,  will  be  enhanced,  as  RH  interventions  will  improve  female  health  and
promote female employment.

B.

Analysis of Demand and Need

1.  

Sources of Family Planning Supplies and Services

3.
Recent  surveys  indicate  that  in  Pakistan,  especially  in  the  rural  areas,  RH  services  are
obtained mainly from government sources.  According to the Pakistan Fertility and Family Planning
Survey 1996/97, 41 percent of urban women and 65 percent of rural women obtained FP methods
through government sources. Results also show that more than 53 percent of FP clients received
their  intrauterile  device  (IUDs),  injectables,  and  surgery  from  public  sector  facilities.  Forty  five
percent  acquired  their  contraceptives  from  private  sector  outlets,  and  a  negligible  proportion  (1.4
percent) obtained theirs from nongovernment organization (NGO) outlets.1

4.
The Pakistan Fertility and Family Planning Survey  also shows that, although 72 percent of
the  clients  obtained  contraceptive  pills  from  private  sector  outlets,  the  actual  sources  are  as
follows: 60 percent from the public sector, 20 percent from social marketing, and 20 percent from
the  commercial  sector.  Similarly,  91  percent  of  injections  came  from  the  public  sector,  8  percent
from  social  marketing,  and  only  1  percent  from  the  commercial  sector.  The  majority  of  the
population,  particularly  rural  residents,  depend  heavily  on  services  provided  by  the  public  sector.
Thus,  the  public  sector  continues  to  play  the  central  role  in  the  health  sector.  Where  the  private
sector provides FP and RH services, the costs to the consumers are higher than those in the public
sector (paras. 12-13).

2.

Unmet Need and Demand

5.
Despite  the  fact  that  knowledge  about  FP  and  RH  has  become  almost  universal  among
women and men (98 percent), a wide gap exists in utilizing that knowledge for contraceptive use.
There is evidence of unmet need for family planning among couples, as many couples who want to
stop or delay another pregnancy are unable to do so. The Pakistan Fertility and Family Planning
Survey  reported  that  about  46  percent  of  currently  married  women  (58  percent  urban  and  41
percent rural) do not want more children, but of these 38 percent are not using any contraceptive.
The survey further indicates that the overall demand for FP is 61.4 percent, of which 43 percent is
for limiting births and 18.5 percent for spacing births; however, only about 24 percent are currently
using contraceptives, 18.8 percent for limiting births, and only 5.1 percent for birth spacing.

6.
Among provinces, North-West Frontier Province (NWFP) has the highest unmet need (40.6
percent) and Sindh has the lowest (34.2 percent). Overall, more than one third of married women
are in need of FP in all provinces. There is unmet need for family planning in all population strata,
including  among  poor  and  illiterate  mothers.  Factors  contributing  to  high  unmet  need  relate  to
traditional  social  and  cultural  values,  low  status  and  limited  mobility  of  women,  and  problems  of
access  to  the  services.  Unmet  need  results  in  a  high  number  of  unwanted  pregnancies,  which
often lead women to resort abortion. Studies indicate that induced abortions, which can endanger
the mother’s life, may be attempted in some way in 10-20 percent of all pregnancies. A focus on
reaching women and men with unmet need through this Project will reduce fertility significantly and
improve mortality and health status indicators among the poor.

C.

Financing RH Expenditures

1.  

Allocations and Expenditures

The  major  components  of  RH  services  relate  to  comprehensive  maternal  and  child  care
7.
including  safe  motherhood,  emergency  obstetric  services,  FP,  and  control  of  reproductive  tract
infections (RTI) and sexually transmitted diseases (STD). Specific expenditure data on RH services
are  not  routinely  collected  in  Pakistan.  The  Social  Action  Program  (SAP)  expenditure  on  basic
health  and  population  welfare  program  can  be  used  to  estimate  the  expenditures  on  RH.  In  its
2000/01  Public  Sector  Development  Program  of  PRs120.5  billion,  the  Government  allocated
PRs14.0 billion to basic health services, about one third of which would have been spent on RH,
and PRs2.2 billion to the population welfare program (PWP). Hence, the RH budget is estimated at
about PRs7 billion ($117 million) per year.

8.
Since  the  inception  of  the  PWP,  total  funding  to  the  population  program  had  risen  slowly
until  the  late  1970s.  Subsequently  the  Government’s  commitment  to  PWP  was  demonstrated  by
the significant increase in its funding from PRs2.3 billion during 1983-1988 to PRs15 billion for the
period  1998-2003.  During  the  Eighth  Five-Year  Plan  (1993-1998),  the  share  of  international
assistance  was  32  percent.  Current  aid  agency  support  for  PWP  is  mainly  through  SAP  and  the
United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA). The health sector has also received major
external support for the RH-related federal programs, and for maternal and child health (MCH)/FP
services.  The  current  major  external  support  for  the  RH  sector  comes  from  SAP,  the  UNFPA
program,  and  the  Women’s  Health  Project.  The  annual  recurrent  cost  of  the  proposed  Project  is
about 2 percent of public spending in the health sector.

9.
The  issue  of  adequacy  of  public  sector  funding  could  be  viewed  from  the  perspective  of
requirements to meet the objectives of public policy and the existing capacity of the public sector

delivery system.2 Presently, the RH program comprises a small proportion of the budget. Given the
large  unmet  needs  of  the  population  and  the  rationale  for  public  sector  involvement,  there  is
adequate  justification  for  a  substantial  increase  in  allocations.  There  is  no  doubt  that,  at  present,
the public sector faces a severe fiscal constraint in view of the Government’s other obligations, in
particular debt services and defense expenditures. There is little room for bringing about a major
increase in public health spending without external support.

2. 

Households’ Ability to Pay

According to the Household Integrated Economic Survey of 1996/97, the average monthly
10.
expenditures on health care increase as income levels rise, except for the lowest income group (up
to PRs1,000) in urban areas, for which health expenditures appear relatively higher than those for
higher income groups.  For each income group, as well as for the overall population, the share of
health  care  expenditures  in  the  total  household  budget  is  higher  for  rural  residents  (3.1  percent)
than for those in urban areas (2.4 percent); this is mainly due to the lower household budgets of
rural people.  Nevertheless, this share of health care expenditures in the overall household budget
is very low, i.e., it varies between 2 and 3 percent for all income classes.

11. While household spending on health care is low, statistical evidence for Pakistan suggests
that the low-income classes in both urban as well rural areas dissave, i.e., on average, spend more
than  their  incomes,  up  to  monthly  income  levels  of  almost  PRs3,500-PRs4,000.    This  reflects  a
very low ability to pay for any extra expenditure due to either more services consumed or higher
charges for existing services.

3.

User Charges in Reproductive Health

12.
Imposition  or  increase  of  user  charges  on  social  services  is  a  major  issue  in  Pakistan.  In
this context, the social benefits of providing the service to low-income groups outweigh the private
benefits. However, the key question is whether raising the price of RH services will affect the users’
ability  to  pay  and  significantly  reduce  the  use  of  service  demanded,  and  whether  some  form  of
subsidy is required.

RH services are provided at a nominal cost. In population welfare services, clients pay for
13.
commodities.  In  the  health  services,  clients  pay  a  registration  fee.  Family  health  workers  do  not
have  to  charge.  This  difference  in  pricing  policy  has  resulted  in  frequent  nonavailability  of
contraceptives in health services. In addition, clients report having paid more for services in public
health  outlets.  One  study3  estimated  that  an  average  client's  mean  expenditures  on  delivery  in
Government hospitals are PRs590 (ranging from PRs258 to PRs2,096) compared with the formal
average charges of PRs24. However, these services cost more in NGOs and private clinics.

4. 

Potential for Cost Recovery

14.
The  estimated  cost  of  protection  against  conception  for  one  year  per  couple  varies  by
method, but in any case is low. The prices charged by the public sector reflect a policy support for
intrauterine  devices  and  injectables.  More  recently,  there  was  a  debate  about  charging  more  for
contraceptives in view of limited public resources and unavailability of grant financing.

negligible  percentage  (0.4  percent  in  urban  and  0.9  percent  in  rural  areas)  of  respondents  in  a

by raising prices of RH services is presently not advisable as it would reduce affordability to a large

quality  of  care,  however,  may  encourage  higher  levels  of  service  utilization  and  justify  a  small

have  any  apparent  affect  on  contraceptive  prevalence  in  view  of  large  unmet  demand  for  these
services. However, it may affect the poor who would benefit most from FP. Moreover, unit costs in
Pakistan is expected to stay low for the next few years as international evidence suggests that unit
costs start to rise once contraceptive prevalence is above 40-50 percent.

D.

Cost Effectiveness of RH services

15.
Benefits  from  the  Project  are  estimated  using  the  disabilityadjusted  life  years  approach.
This approach entails constructing a composite index of the years of health life lost due to disease,
disability, or death, and the years of life gained. The procedure for calculating the disabilityadjusted
life years is detailed in ADB’s Economic Analysis of Health Sector Projects.

16.
Based  on  the  health  conditions  for  which  data  are  available  in  Pakistan,  i.e.,  maternal,
nutrition, infant-related, childhood cluster, and STDs, the Project’s cost-effectiveness is calculated.
Since Pakistan has been classified as a “data poor” country in the context of disabilityadjusted life
years  calculations,  “crude”  estimates  are  given.  Table  A12.1  presents  the  total  number  of
disabilityadjusted  life  years  that  can  be  potentially  saved  by  the  six-year  Project.  Incidence  of
diseases  and  disability-adjusted  life  years  are  based  on  the  1994  National  Health  Survey  of
Pakistan  and  are  calculated  for  a  typical  year  during  the  project  implementation  period  and  four
years after. The incidence and disability-adjusted life years were increased by 20 percent to adjust
for poor rural populations being targeted under the Project. The Project is assumed to reduce most
types  of  morbidity  by  only  10  percent,  which  is  low  but  reflects  a  realistic  estimate  of  coverage,
absorptive capacity and effectiveness of interventions in the districts.

17.

range  is  $15-$75.  It  is  low  because  of  the  large  target  population  being  reached  with  low-cost
